description: Borrowed from French rendez-vous (“appointment”), noun derived from second person plural imperative of se rendre (“to go to”), literally, “[you (imperative)] go to, get yourself to [a place]”.

examples: I have a rendezvous with a friend in three hours.

entries.meaning: An agreement to meet at a certain place and time.
examples: Get the party started at the rendezvous at oh six hours.

entries.meaning: A place appointed for a meeting, or at which persons customarily meet.
(military) The appointed place for troops, or for the ships of a fleet, to assemble; also, a place for enlistment.
(astronautics) A set of orbital maneuvers during which two spacecraft arrive at the same orbit and approach to a very close distance.

verbs.description: rendezvous (third-person singular simple present rendezvouses or rendezvous, present participle rendezvousing, simple past and past participle rendezvoused)

entries.meaning: To meet at an agreed time and place.
examples: Let's rendezvous at the bordello at 8:00 and go from there.
